key_points: President Donald Trump announced he will not attend President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration.
This decision breaks the tradition of peaceful transition and is seen as an act of defiance.
Biden agrees with Trump's decision, calling him an "embarrassment" and saying it's a "good thing".
Historically, outgoing and incoming presidents attend the inauguration together, symbolizing smooth transition.
Former Presidents Obama, Bush, and Clinton, except the ailing Jimmy Carter, will attend Biden's inauguration.
Trump's announcement came amidst discussions of his second impeachment and after he was banned from Twitter.
Trump has continued to falsely claim that he won the election and has alleged widespread voter fraud.
Vice President Mike Pence's attendance is still uncertain, though Biden welcomes him.
Historian Douglas Brinkley suggests Trump's absence portrays him as a "sore loser" and undermines democracy.
Discussions about invoking the 25th Amendment or impeachment are ongoing amidst concerns about Trump's actions in his final days.
spokespersons: Devin O'Malley (Spokesperson for Vice President Pence)
